{{Infobox person | name = Cari Champion | image = First Take Salute the Troops broadcast (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Champion during a broadcast of ''[[First Take (TV series)|First Take]]'' in 2014 | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|June 1 1978}} | birth_place = [[Pasadena, California]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] | occupation = [[Broadcast journalist]], [[television personality]] | credits = [[Tennis Channel]] (2009–2012)
''[[First Take (TV series)|First Take]]'' (2012–2015)
''[[SportsCenter]]'' (2015–2018)
''[[SportsNation (TV series)|SportsNation]]'' (2018) | website = {{url|carichampion.com}} }} '''Cari Champion''' (born June 1, 1978) is an American [[broadcast journalist]] and [[television personality]]. She has worked as an [[News presenter|anchor]] and reporter for the [[Tennis Channel]] and as the host of [[ESPN2]]'s ''[[First Take (TV series)|First Take]]''. In July 2015, Champion became an anchor for [[ESPN]]'s flagship program ''[[SportsCenter]]''. == Early life == Champion was born on June 1, 1978 and raised in [[Pasadena, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/next-espns-cari-champion |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |title=Next: ESPN's Cari Champion |work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]] |date=December 27, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HKFqxKXS?url=http://www.vibe.com/article/next-espns-cari-champion |archivedate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} Champion attended the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA), where she majored in [[English studies|English]] and minored in [[mass communications]]. She wrote for the ''[[Daily Bruin]]'' and was inspired to pursue a career in [[journalism]] by UCLA alumni, including Matea Gold of the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'', who was the editor in chief of the student newspaper.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/CariChampion/status/464149972191948800|title=Cari Champion on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-05-13|language=en}} Champion was drawn to journalism with goals of transforming negative stereotypes of [[African American]]s: "I wanted to give people a voice that didn't have a voice. I'm always fighting for the underdog. I don't know where I got it from, but I've been like that all my life. That's why I love journalism."{{cite journal|last=DeFrancesco |first=Tracey |date=August 2011 |volume=4 |issue=5 |url=http://tennisviewmag.com/pastissuearticle/cari-champion-the-purpose-driven-reporter/ |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110803131221/http://tennisviewmag.com/pastissuearticle/cari-champion-the-purpose-driven-reporter/ |archivedate=August 3, 2011 |journal=Tennis View Magazine |title=Cari Champion: The Purpose Driven Reporter |location=Seminole |dead-url=yes }} In her junior year, she studied in [[Washington, D.C.]] and earned an internship at [[CNN]].{{cite web|url=http://magazine.ucla.edu/exclusives/espns-referee/ |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |title=ESPN's Referee - Web Exclusive |work=UCLA Magazine Online |publisher=UCLA Marketing & Communications and UCLA Alumni Association |last=Feinberg |first=Paul |date=February 4, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HKGrj8t1?url=http://magazine.ucla.edu/exclusives/espns-referee/ |archivedate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} Champion graduated from UCLA in 1998, with an English degree. == Career == === Early broadcasting work === Champion began her broadcasting career at several television stations. She moved to West Virginia for her first reporting job. She later said of working there: "I was a one-man-band carrying a camera and a tripod and that was God-awful. But I loved it because I wanted to do it. I always wanted to be a reporter." She was a reporter at the [[Orange County Newschannel]] in [[Santa Ana, California]] before joining [[WPTV-TV]] in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]] in the same capacity in 2002.{{cite journal|page=53|volume=132|journal=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|title=none|location=New York}} In November 2007, while working as an anchor for [[WGCL-TV]] in Atlanta, Champion was fired for allegedly uttering a profanity over the air. She appealed the firing and said in an interview for the [[Robert C. Maynard Institute for Journalism Education|Maynard Institute]] that the [[floor director]] had not cued her and her co-anchor following a commercial break, and that the microphone picked up a conversation they were having about an unhandy mechanical screenwriter: "I called the screenwriter a 'mothersucka' not the [[f-bomb]]."{{cite news|last=Ho |first=Rodney |date=December 19, 2007 |url=http://alt.coxnewsweb.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/accessatlanta/radiotalk/entries/2007/12/19/1219_cari_champ.html |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |title=Cari Champion gets a 2nd chance |newspaper=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HKLBkw1y?url=http://alt.coxnewsweb.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/accessatlanta/radiotalk/entries/2007/12/19/1219_cari_champ.html |archivedate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} She was rehired in January 2008, but left shortly after in March for a broadcasting job outside of Atlanta.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AT&p_theme=at&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=126ED8A8A27A1490&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=June 13, 2013|last=Eldridge|first=Richard L.|date=March 20, 2008|title=Changing Channels|newspaper=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution}} {{subscription required}} After moving to Florida, Champion covered news such as [[human interest stories]] and devastating hurricanes in the state. While working as a reporter there, she developed an affinity for tennis after covering players such as [[Venus Williams|Venus]] and [[Serena Williams]]: "They made me love the sport even more. They opened the door to tennis for so many different people." She subsequently auditioned for the [[Tennis Channel]]'s burgeoning news department and was one of three women selected from a pool of more than fifty candidates. She joined the network in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://jwww.tennischannel.com/programs/talent/cari_champion.aspx |title=Cari Champion |publisher=[[Tennis Channel]] |accessdate=June 13, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HLgR8c40?url=http://jwww.tennischannel.com/programs/talent/cari_champion.aspx |archivedate=June 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} Champion worked as a courtside reporter, and anchored the channel's ''Court Report'' news segment. She also worked as an entertainment reporter for the [[Starz (TV channel)|Starz]] network and shows such as ''[[omg! Insider|The Insider]]'' and ''[[Hollywood 411]]''. === Career at ESPN === On October 1, 2012, Champion joined [[ESPN]] as the new host of [[ESPN2]]'s live debate show ''[[First Take (TV series)|First Take]]''.{{cite web|last=Nesheim |first=Jay Jay |date=September 26, 2012 |url=http://espnmediazone.com/us/press-releases/2012/09/cari-champion-joins-espn-as-host-of-first-take-as-show-ratings-surge/ |title=Cari Champion Joins ESPN as Host of First Take as Show Ratings Surge |publisher=[[ESPN|ESPN MediaZone]] |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HKMAWj6A?url=http://espnmediazone.com/us/press-releases/2012/09/cari-champion-joins-espn-as-host-of-first-take-as-show-ratings-surge/ |archivedate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} She was hired over [[Heidi Watney]] and [[Jemele Hill]] for the job.{{cite web|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/1329685-espn-reportedly-welcomes-tennis-channels-cari-champion-to-host-first-take |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HKLjtvNX?url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/1329685-espn-reportedly-welcomes-tennis-channels-cari-champion-to-host-first-take |archivedate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=no |last=Zaldivar |first=Gabe |date=September 10, 2012 |title=ESPN Reportedly Welcomes Tennis Channel's Cari Champion to Host "First Take" |publisher=[[Bleacher Report]] |df= }} As the show's host, she [[discussion moderator|moderated]] debates between sports pundits [[Skip Bayless]] and [[Stephen A. Smith]], whom she said had "the biggest, strongest personalities in the building".{{cite web|date=June 18, 2015|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/s/espn-cari-champion-promoted-sportscenter-anchor-exclusive-032642566.html|title=ESPN’s Cari Champion Promoted to ‘SportsCenter’ Anchor (Exclusive)|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=June 19, 2015}} After proposing ideas for stories to ESPN, Champion made her journalistic debut for the network on November 4, 2014 when she profiled and interviewed American football quarterback [[Cam Newton]] in a segment for ''[[E:60]]''.{{cite web|last=Kreiswirth |first=Carrie |date=November 4, 2014 |url=http://www.espnfrontrow.com/2014/11/first-takes-cari-champion-debuts-e60-correspondent-profiles-cam-newton/ |title=First Take's Cari Champion debuts as E:60 correspondent, profiles Cam Newton |publisher=ESPN Front Row |accessdate=November 6, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Tt5CW73t?url=http://www.espnfrontrow.com/2014/11/first-takes-cari-champion-debuts-e60-correspondent-profiles-cam-newton/ |archivedate=November 6, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} That same day, she was the target of racist and sexist [[Twitter|tweets]] from comedian [[Artie Lange]], who jokingly portrayed himself and Champion in a sexual fantasy set during [[slavery in the United States|slavery]]. Lange tweeted an apology to Champion the following day and ESPN issued a statement to ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' that rebuked Lange's tweets, while Champion did not respond publicly.{{cite news|last=D'Zurilla |first=Christie |date=November 5, 2014 |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-artie-lange-cari-champion-racist-sex-fantasy-twitter-espn-20141105-story.html |title=Artie Lange explains his racist sex fantasy about ESPN's Cari Champion |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=November 6, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Tt5BVC4N?url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-artie-lange-cari-champion-racist-sex-fantasy-twitter-espn-20141105-story.html |archivedate=November 6, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} After petitioning ESPN for six months to become an anchor on ''[[SportsCenter]]'', Champion was promoted to the position in June 2015. She hosted her last episode of ''First Take'' on June 19 and began anchoring morning editions of ''SportsCenter'' in July.{{cite news|last=Bonesteel |first=Matt |issue=June 19 |year=2015 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2015/06/19/cari-champion-escapes-espns-first-take-for-sportscenter/ |title=Cari Champion escapes ESPN’s ‘First Take’ for ‘SportsCenter’ |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=June 19, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZPWR2R8k?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2015/06/19/cari-champion-escapes-espns-first-take-for-sportscenter/ |archivedate=June 19, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} On March 12, 2018, Champion became the host of ESPN's [[SportsNation (TV series)|SportsNation]] along with co-hosts [[LZ Granderson]] and [[Marcellus Wiley]].{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Olivia|date=February 20, 2018|url=https://espnmediazone.com/us/press-releases/2018/02/cari-champion-make-sportsnation-debut-march-12/|title=Cari Champion to Make SportsNation Debut on March 12|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=March 12, 2018}} == Personal life == Champion grew up as an avid basketball fan. She is a fan of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and the [[UCLA Bruins]]. According to her, she is 6 feet 1 inch tall "with heels". Before working on the show, Champion was an avid watcher of ''First Take'': "I love the barbershop debates that make ''First Take'' feel different than other programs". ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == Further reading == * {{cite news|last=Best|first=Neil|date=July 25, 2015|url=http://www.newsday.com/sports/media/cari-champion-espn-s-first-take-needs-to-evolve-1.10674042|title=Cari Champion: ESPN's First Take 'needs to evolve'|newspaper=[[Newsday]]|location=Melville|accessdate=December 13, 2015}} * {{cite web|last=Collins |first=J. J. |date=May 2012 |url=http://www.iwg-gti.org/catalyst/may-2012/q-a-with-renowned-sports-journal/ |title=Q&A with renowned sports journalist Cari Champion: An interview by J.J. Collins |work=Catalyst eNewsletter |publisher=International Working Group on Women and Sport |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HKFbeqsG?url=http://www.iwg-gti.org/catalyst/may-2012/q-a-with-renowned-sports-journal/ |archivedate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} * {{cite journal|last=Harris |first=Christopher |issue=July 31 |year=2015 |url=http://www.ebony.com/entertainment-culture/cari-champion-joins-sportscenter-interview-111#.Vb42rYzD_Dc |title=Cari Champion Joins SportsCenter! [INTERVIEW] |journal=[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]] |accessdate=August 2, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aU7VweEV?url=http://www.ebony.com/entertainment-culture/cari-champion-joins-sportscenter-interview-111/2 |archivedate=August 2, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.carichampion.com/}} * {{IMDb name|id=nm3167341}} * {{YouTube|user=ESPN1stTake|ESPN First Take}} {{ESPN}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Champion, Cari}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:African-American television hosts]] [[Category:American television journalists]] [[Category:African-American television personalities]] [[Category:American television sports anchors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Pasadena, California]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles alumni]] [[Category:CNN people]] [[Category:ESPN people]] [[Category:African-American women journalists]] [[Category:African-American journalists]] [[Category:Sports journalists]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox UK Racecourse | Name = Folkestone | Image = [[File:Folkestone racecourse logo.jpg]] | Caption = Folkestone Racecourse logo | Website = http://www.folkestone-racecourse.co.uk | Location = [[Westenhanger]], [[Kent]] | Owner = [[Arena Leisure Plc]] | Channel = [[At The Races]] | CourseType = [[Flat racing|Flat]]
[[National Hunt]] | Prev = [[Fakenham Racecourse|Fakenham]] | Next = [[Fontwell Park Racecourse|Fontwell Park]] }} [[File:Folkestone racecourse, Westenhanger.jpg|thumb|Grandstand seen from the station]] '''Folkestone Racecourse''' was a [[thoroughbred horse racing]] venue in southeast England, until it closed in 2012. It is located in [[Westenhanger]], by junction 11 of the [[M20 motorway]] and about two miles west of [[Folkestone]]. Since 2013 the venue has hosted the [[War and Peace show]] previously held at the [[The Hop Farm Country Park|Hop Farm]] at [[Beltring]].[http://www.thewarandpeacerevival.co.uk/ War and Peace Revival website ''(Retrieved 6 May 2013)''] The course remains closed and all running rail and steeplechase fences have been removed. In May 2016 it was revealed that the land covered by the racecourse forms part of a plan to develop and build housing. ==History== The history of the Westenhanger estate dates back to 1035 when it was owned by [[King Canute]]. The 14th century [[Westenhanger Castle]] can still be seen next to the main grandstand.{{cn|date=January 2017}} The race course was established in 1898, and was a right-handed undulating oval with a run in of 3f and a 7f straight chute.{{cn|date=January 2017}} The centre of the course is farmed, and has a reservoir fed by a pumping station on the west side of the oval. The [[East Stour, Kent|East Stour]] river runs along the western edge of the oval and under the straight course.{{cn|date=January 2017}} In July 2012, [[Arena Leisure]] and [[Northern Racing]], the lessees of the racecourse announced the closure of the racecourse as a temporary measure. Outdated facilities and the delay of a project to build houses on part of the site were given as the reasons for the closure. It was announced that a final decision would be made in 2013.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-19014895 |title=Hereford and Folkestone racecourses to close |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=27 July 2012}} Folkestone held its last scheduled meeting on 18 December 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-20769372 |title=Folkestone Racecourse holds 'last' horse racing meeting |publisher=BBC News |date=18 December 2012}} Arena Leisure stated in 2012 that the closure was temporary. In 2016 it was revealed that plans drawn up by [[Folkestone and Hythe (District)|Folkestone and Hythe]] Council include the racecourse area for building houses in a development known as Otterpool Garden Town. By December 2017 much of the racecourse infrastructure had fallen into disrepair and there was no prospect of any resumption of racing at the venue.{{cite web|last1=Mottershead|first1=Lee|title=Unkempt and unloved: Folkestone revisited five years on from its closure|url=https://www.racingpost.com/news/christmas-countdown/the-weeds-are-thriving-at-folkestone-where-racing-is-firmly-in-the-past/312226|website=Racing Post|accessdate=29 December 2017}} ==Use by RAF== The racecourse was first used by aviation when a flying meeting was held in September 1910. Three aircraft were present, watched by a large crowd.{{cite book |last= Lee |first= David W. |title= Action Stations Revisited, Volume 3 South East England |year=2010 |publisher= Crecy Publishing Ltd |isbn= 978-0-85979-110-6| page= 304}} Between 1940 and 1941 the racecourse was used as a decoy airfield with dummy aircraft placed to look like an active airfield. On 23 April 1944 [[No. 660 Squadron RAF|660 Squadron]], an army cooperation squadron of the [[Royal Air Force]], arrived at what was then known as RAF Westenhanger after the nearby village. The squadron based in a tented camp was equipped with [[Taylorcraft Auster|Auster Mark IV]] single-engined liaison aircraft and used the racecourse to practise operations with local army units. On 12 July 1944 the squadron of 12 Austers escorted by a [[Supermarine Walrus]] rescue flying boat left Westenhanger for France. The airfield was then restored back to use as a racecourse. Rubble from wartime buildings can be seen on the north side of the straight course where it meets the oval. [[File:Westenhanger Castle - geograph.org.uk - 889584.jpg|thumb|Westenhanger Castle.]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.folkestone-racecourse.co.uk Folkestone Racecourse (Official website)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060825010717/http://www.gg.com/folkestone Course guide on GG.COM] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927005518/http://www.attheraces.com/course.asp?CID=9 Course guide on At The Races] {{coord |51|5|38|N|1|2|1|E|type:landmark_scale:10000_region:GB-KEN|display=title}} {{Horse racing in Great Britain}} [[Category:Royal Air Force stations in Kent]] [[Category:Sports venues in Kent]] [[Category:Defunct horse racing venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1898]] [[Category:1898 establishments in England]] [[Category:2012 disestablishments in England]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Harvard Stadium | nickname = Soldiers Field | image = Harvard Stadium aerial axonometric.JPG | image_size = 220 | caption = Aerial view from the south in 2015 | location = 95 N. Harvard Street
{{nowrap|[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S.}} | broke_ground = July 1903 | opened = November 14, 1903
{{Years or months ago|1903}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Harvard University]] | operator = Harvard University | surface = [[FieldTurf]] (2006–present)
Natural grass (1903–2005)Lisa Kennelly, [http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=512722 Extreme Makeover: Harvard Stadium], ''Harvard Crimson'' April 13, 2006. | construction_cost = $310,000
([[United States dollar|$]]{{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|310000|1903}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} {{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Prof. Louis J. Johnson,
Class of 1887 (his name was Lewis, he was my grandfather) | tenants = [[Harvard Crimson]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1903–present)

[[Boston Cannons]] ([[Major League Lacrosse|MLL]]) (2007–2014, 2016–present)
[[Boston Breakers (WPS)|Boston Breakers]] ([[Women's Professional Soccer|WPS]]) (2009–2011)
[[Boston Breakers (NWSL)|Boston Breakers]] ([[National Women's Soccer League|NWSL]]) (2014)
[[Boston Brawlers]] ([[Fall Experimental Football League|FXFL]]) (2014) | seating_capacity = 30,323 (1952–present)
57,166 (1929–1951)
42,000 (1904–1928)
20,000 (1903){{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/information/facilities/Harvard_Stadium_Football_History|title=Harvard Stadium Football History|publisher=Harvard University|accessdate=April 11, 2016}} }} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Harvard Stadium | nrhp_type = nhl | image = | caption = | location= 60 N. Harvard St., [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | coordinates = {{coord|42|21|59|N|71|7|38|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Boston Metro#Massachusetts#USA | built = 1903 | architect = McKim, Charles F.; Et al. | architecture = Classical Revival | added = February 27, 1987 | area = {{convert|11|acre}} | refnum = 87000757{{NRISref|version=2009a}} }} '''Harvard Stadium''' is a U-shaped [[college football]] stadium in the northeast [[United States]], located in the [[Allston, Massachusetts|Allston]] neighborhood of [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. The stadium is owned and operated by [[Harvard University]] and is home to the [[Harvard Crimson football]] program. The stadium's [[seating capacity]] is 30,323.{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/information/facilities/harvardstadium|title=Harvard|work=Harvard}} Built in 1903, it was a pioneering execution of [[reinforced concrete]] in the construction of large structures. Because of its early importance in these areas, and its influence on the design of later stadiums, it was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1987.{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=BOS.8286|title=NRHP nomination for Harvard Stadium|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2014-06-02}} The stadium is the nation's oldest permanent concrete structure dedicated to intercollegiate athletics. It seated up to 57,166 in the past, as permanent steel stands (completing a straight-sided oval){{cite news |url=https://www.digitalcommonwealth.org/search/commonwealth:5h73r100b |work=Digital Commonwealth |location=Newton, Massachusetts) |title=Aerial view of Harvard Stadium |date=1930 |accessdate=December 1, 2017}} were installed in the stadium's northeast end zone in 1929. They were torn down after the 1951 season, due to deterioration and reduced attendance. Afterward, there were smaller temporary steel bleachers across the stadium's open end until the building of the Murr Center (which is topped by the new scoreboard) in 1998. Harvard Stadium hosted one Boston Patriots season in [[1970 Boston Patriots season|1970]]. It was their first season in the [[National Football League|NFL]] after the [[AFL–NFL merger]] and their last before becoming the [[New England Patriots]]. The team moved to [[Foxboro Stadium|Schaefer Stadium]] in [[Foxborough, Massachusetts|Foxborough]] [[1971 New England Patriots season|the following season]]. ==History== Harvard Stadium was constructed on {{convert|31|acre}} of land known as Soldiers Field, donated to Harvard University by [[Henry Lee Higginson]] in 1890 as a memorial to Harvard men who had died in the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] {{nowrap|(1861–1865).{{refn|{{cite book|author=Harvard University|title=Education, bricks and mortar: Harvard buildings and their contribution to the advancement of learning|chapter=Memorial Hall|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aRI8AAAAIAAJ|year=1949|page=82n}} }}}} The structure, similar in shape to the [[Panathenaic Stadium]], was completed in just 4½ months costing $310,000. Much of the funds raised came from a 25th reunion gift by Harvard's Class of 1879. It is the home of Harvard's [[American football|football]] team. The stadium also hosted the Crimson [[track and field]] teams until 1984 and was the home of the [[Boston Patriots]] during the 1970 season, until [[Schaefer Stadium]] opened the following year. Lewis Jerome Johnson, professor of civil engineering at Harvard, was a consultant to the design team for the stadium. It is historically significant that this stadium represents the first vertical concrete structure to employ reinforced structural concrete. Prior to the erection of the stadium in 1902, reinforced structural concrete was used in horizontal, that is flooring, sidewalks, etc., design only. Prof. Johnson was the engineer of note responsible for incorporating the concept into the vertical structure of the stadium design. There is a plaque dedicating the stadium to his honor on the east end wall outside the stadium. Harvard installed both [[FieldTurf]] and lights in 2006.{{cite web|title=Harvard Stadium|url=https://www.bostoncannons.com/harvard-stadium|publisher=''Boston Cannons''|accessdate=April 24, 2016}} In [[2007 Harvard Crimson football team|2007]], Harvard played its first night game at the stadium, winning 24–17 over [[Brown Bears football|Brown University]] on September 22.{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/ncf/recap/_/id/272650108 |work=ESPN |agency=Associated Press |title=Harvard 24, Brown 17 |date=September 22, 2007|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2007/9/23/football-topples-brown-in-historic-night/ |work=Harvard Crimson |location=(Cambridge, Massachusetts) |last=Glenn |first=Malcolm A. |title=Football topples Brown in historic night game |date=September 23, 2007 |accessdate=December 1, 2017}} ===Impact on American Football=== In the early 20th century, [[American football]] was an extremely violent sport. 18 players died and 159 were seriously injured in 1905 alone.{{cite web|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2003/09/first-and-100.html|title=First and 100|publisher=''The Harvard Magazine''|accessdate=April 12, 2016}} There was a widespread movement to outlaw the game but U.S. President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] intervened and demanded the rules of the game be reformed. In 1906, Roosevelt met with representatives from 62 colleges and universities and formed the Intercollegiate Football Conference, the predecessor of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]].{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/rr/news/topics/football1.html|title=The 1905 Movement to Reform Football|publisher=Library of Congress document|accessdate=April 12, 2016}} The committee's purpose was to develop a uniform set of rules and regulations to make the game safer. A leading proposal, at the time, was widening the field to allow more running room and reduce serious collisions. While it was popular among committee members, Harvard objected. Their recently completed stadium could not accommodate a larger field. Because of the permanent nature of Harvard Stadium, the proposal was rejected and the [[forward pass]] was legalized in April 1906.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/22/sports/ncaafootball/22harvard.html?_r=0|title=Saturday Night Lights: Harvard Stadium Joins the 21st Century|publisher=''New York Times''|accessdate=April 12, 2016}} Harvard Stadium led to the creation of two of the most fundamental aspects of modern American football: standard field dimensions and the legal forward pass. ===Other events=== Harvard Stadium was the site of the [[United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|U.S. Olympic Trials]] for men's track and field in 1920, 1924, and [[1928 United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|1928]]. It is also the host of [[music festival]]s like the [[Amandla Festival]], where [[Jamaica]]n reggae legend [[Bob Marley]] performed a historic concert in 1979. [[Janis Joplin]] performed her last show at the stadium in 1970, shortly before her death. During the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] held in Los Angeles, the stadium hosted several [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics|soccer]] preliminaries.[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1984/1984v1pt1.pdf 1984 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. Part 1. pp. 129-31. In 2007, the [[Boston Cannons]], a professional lacrosse team for [[Major League Lacrosse]], moved their home site to the stadium. They previously played at [[Boston University]]'s [[Nickerson Field]].[[Malcom Glenn|Malcom A. Glenn]], [http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=517262 Improved Stadium Scores Pro Team], Harvard Crimson, February 23, 2007. Harvard installed [[FieldTurf]] and lights in 2006, allowing it to become the home stadium of the [[Boston Cannons]]. Beginning on April 11, 2009, Harvard Stadium became the home field of the [[Boston Breakers (WPS)|Boston Breakers]] of the [[Women's Professional Soccer]] (WPS) league when they beat [[Saint Louis Athletica]] 2–0. Harvard and the [[Boston Bruins]] have begun talks about making a bid for the stadium to serve as the host of the [[National Hockey League]]'s 2024 [[NHL Winter Classic]] to coincide with the Boston Bruins' 100th anniversary year. If awarded the game, the Boston Bruins are expected to ask the NHL to have the [[Montreal Canadiens]] serve as the opposition. === 1984 Summer Olympics === [[Association football]] games played at Harvard Stadium during the [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Summer Olympics]] {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:85%;" style="text-align:center" |- !Date !Time ([[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |July 29||19.30||align=left|{{fb|NOR}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–0||align=left|{{fb|CHI}}||Group A||style="text-align:center;"|25,000 |- |July 30||19.30||align=left|{{fb|CAN}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1||align=left|{{fb|IRQ}}||Group B||style="text-align:center;"|16,730 |- |July 31||19.00||align=left|{{fb|NOR}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–2||align=left|'''{{fb|FRA}}'''||Group A||style="text-align:center;"|27,832 |- |August 1||19.00||align=left|'''{{fb|CMR}}'''||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||align=left|{{fb|IRQ}}||Group B||style="text-align:center;"|20,000 |- |August 2||19.00||align=left|{{fb|QAT}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–2||align=left|'''{{fb|NOR}}'''||Group A||style="text-align:center;"|17,529 |- |August 3||19.00||align=left|{{fb|CMR}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–3||align=left|'''{{fb|CAN}}'''||Group B||style="text-align:center;"|27,261 |} {{clear}} ==Location== [[File:Harvard stadium 2009h.JPG|thumb|The stadium in 2009]] Although most of Harvard's campus is in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], the stadium and most other intercollegiate athletic facilities, along with [[Harvard Business School]], lie to the south, across the [[Charles River]], in the nearby Allston neighborhood of Boston. The stadium is the most iconic piece of the Soldiers Field athletic complex, which also includes the baseball stadium, outdoor track, an artificial turf field hockey/lacrosse field, two soccer stadiums, pools, Beren Tennis Center (outdoor), the Gordon Indoor Track, Dillon Fieldhouse, [[Lavietes Pavilion]], and [[Bright Hockey Center]]. Newell Boathouse, home of Harvard's men's crew, lies across Soldiers Field Road on the banks of the Charles. The stadium's horseshoe opens to the northeast, towards the river, and the press box is at the top of the northwest sideline's grandstand. The running track has been removed; it was non-standard, with long straights and tight turns, and the outside lanes were very near the stadium walls. ==Gallery== File:Harvard Stadium Dedication Plaque - 1903.jpg|Dedication Plaque by the Class of 1879–1903 File:Harvard Stadium Rededication Plaque - 1953.jpg|50th Anniversary Plaque – 1953 File:Harvard Stadium 1903.png|Under construction (1903) File:Harvard Stadium - 1905.jpg|Harvard-Yale game of 1905 File:Harvard Stadium - 1903 Greek Play.jpg|Performance of Greek Play – 1905 File:Harvard Stadium - 1910 Hockey (Hi-Res).jpg|Hockey was played in Harvard Stadium until World War I File:Harvard Stadium - 1911 Lew G.jpg|Harvard-Yale game of 1911 File:Harvard Stadium - 1915.jpg|Aerial view with trapezoidal temporary wooden stands in place circa 1915–1928 File:Harvard Scoreboard - 2006 (1).jpg|Scoreboard – 1984–2007 File:Harvard Stadium - 2000 Ivy exterior.jpg|Exterior ivy, removed in 2006 File:Harvard Stadium - 2006 1.jpg|Aerial view of the 2006 Harvard-Yale game – the Murr Center (built in 1998) now sits across the open end of the stadium. File:Harvard Scoreboard - 2008.jpg|Scoreboard – 2008–present Image:Harvard Stadium, Dudesleeper.jpg|The stadium's southwest-facing exterior. Image:Harvard Stadium end view.jpg|View from the southern end of the [[colonnade]]. The Murr Center, an indoor recreation facility built in 1998, is the building at the end of the stadium. Image:HarvardStadium1.jpg| 2008 Image:HarvardStadium2.jpg| 2008 Image:Harvard Stadium.jpg| 2008 ==See also== * [[Harvard Crimson]] * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] * [[List of {{Orphan|date=April 2014}}
This is a list of '''foreign players''' in the '''[[Adeccoligaen|Norwegian First Division]]''', which commenced play in 1949. The following players must meet both of the following two criteria: #Have played at least one Premier League game. Players who were signed by Premier League clubs, but only played in lower league, cup and/or European games, or did not play in any competitive games at all, are not included. #Are considered foreign, determined by the following: ::A player is considered foreign if he is not eligible to play for [[Norway national football team]], more specifically: ::*If a player has been capped on international level, the national team is used; if he has been capped by more than one country, the highest level (or the most recent) team is used. ::*If a player has not been capped on international level, his country of birth is used, except those who were born abroad from Norwegian parents or moved to Norway at a young age, and those who clearly indicated to have switched his nationality to another nation.

[[Seoul United FC|Seoul United]] (2011–present) | seating_capacity = 446 }} '''Madeul Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Nowon-gu]], [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]]. ==External links== * [http://allstadiums.ru/aziya/stadiony-yujnoy-korei/madeul-stadium.html Madeul Stadium] {{ru icon}} {{Seoul United||state=collapsed}} {{coord|37|38|39|N|127|03|28|E|type:landmark_source:kolossus-kowiki|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in South Korea]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2008]] [[Category:Sports venues in Seoul]] [[Category:Seoul United FC]] {{SouthKorea-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''medal table''' is a collection of all [[medals]], ordered by participants, clubs, or participant countries, who have been awarded in the history of an event.
Usually gold medals are the first, silver medals as second and bronze medals as the third criterion for the rank list. The term is often used in connection with the [[Olympic Games]], where a medal table is also created for each individual [[sport]].
==See also== * [[Olympic medal table]]
[[Category:Medal tables| ]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Merlo Field | image = [[File:Merlo Field.JPG|250px]]| fullname = Harry A. Merlo Field | nickname = | location = [[University Park, Portland, Oregon]] | built = 1990 | opened = | owner = [[University of Portland]] | seating_capacity = 4,892 | tenants = [[Portland Pilots]] ([[NCAA]])
[[Portland Timbers 2]] ([[United Soccer League|USL]]) | dimensions = 109 m × 69 m
120 yds × 75 yds| surface = Natural Grass | cost = $1.2 Million }} '''Harry A. Merlo Field at the [[Clive Charles]] Soccer Complex''' is a 4,892-capacity [[soccer-specific stadium]] in [[Portland, Oregon]] on the campus of the [[University of Portland]] where it serves as home to the school's [[soccer]] teams. From March 29, 2015 until the end of 2016, the stadium played host to the [[Portland Timbers]]' USL side [[Portland Timbers 2]]. ==History== The stadium was constructed in 1990.[http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/united_states/oregon.shtml Stadiums in the United States: Oregon. World Stadiums.] Retrieved on April 3, 2008. It is named after [[Harry Merlo|Harry A. Merlo]], a businessman and philanthropist. Merlo Field hosted a quarter-final game in the 2001 [[NCAA Women's Soccer Championship|Women’s NCAA Division I Championship]][http://www.soccertimes.com/ncaa/2001/women.htm 2001 Division I Tournament.] SoccerTimes.com. Retrieved on April 3, 2008. and then first and second round games of the tournament in 2003.[http://www.soccertimes.com/ncaa/2003/womentourney.htm 2003 NCAA Women's Division I Tournament.] SoccerTimes.com. Retrieved on April 3, 2008. In 2004, the school added six light standards to illuminate the field to allow for night games at the venue.[http://www.up.edu/news/shownews.asp?id=2831 Inaugural night game featuring UP’s women’s soccer team set for 7 p.m. Friday, Sept. 10.]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The University of Portland, August 27, 2004. Retrieved April 3, 2008. Pilots’ alumna [[Tiffeny Milbrett]] scored her 100th international goal at Merlo in a game for the [[United States women's national soccer team]] against [[Ukraine]] in July 2005.Anne M. Peterson, The Associated Press. [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2005-07-10-us-women-results_x.htm Milbrett scores 100th as U.S. women rout Ukraine.] ''[[USA TODAY]]'', July 10, 2005. Retrieved on April 3, 2008. In 2005, the Lady Pilots hosted an NCAA tournament semifinal game on their way to a national title.Fowler, Ken. [http://media.www.ndsmcobserver.com/media/storage/paper660/news/2005/11/29/Sports/Nd.Womens.Soccer.Plane.Crash-1115005.shtml ND Women's Soccer: Plane crash.]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''The Observer'', November 29, 2005. Retrieved on April 3, 2008. During the 2007 season the Pilots averaged 3,652 people per game in attendance at the 4,892 seat stadium for the women’s home matches, leading the country in average attendance for the third straight year.Hays, Graham. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/columns/story?columnist=hays_graham&id=3107829 NCAA does disservice to the game by sending Portland on the road.] ESPN.com, November 13, 2007. Retrieved on April 3, 2008. In March 2008, the [[Portland Timbers (2001–10)|Portland Timbers]] used the facility to host an exhibition match against [[Major League Soccer]]’s [[San Jose Earthquakes]].[http://www.portlandsentinel.com/?q=node/712 Army to invade North Portland.] ''The Sentinel'', March 28, 2008. Retrieved on April 3, 2008. on July 17, 2010, the Portland Timbers held an exhibition match against English Premier league power and Europa League qualifier Manchester City at this facility. The [[Portland Timbers (2001–10)|Portland Timbers]] used Merlo Field as their home pitch during the 2010 USSF D-2 playoffs. Due to the renovation of [[Jeld-Wen Field]],in their first home match as a [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] team, the Timbers used Merlo Field as their home pitch in their [[US Open Cup]] match against [[Chivas USA]], winning 2-0. Starting in 2015 the [[Portland Timbers 2]] will use Merlo Field and their home pitch. ==See also== * [[List of sports venues in Portland, Oregon]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.portlandpilots.com/facilities/#soccer University of Portland Athletic Facilities] {{S-start}} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[Women's College Cup]] | years = 1994 | before = [[Fetzer Field]] | after = [[Fetzer Field]] }} {{end}} {{Sports venues in Portland, Oregon|collapsed}} [[Category:Portland Pilots soccer]] [[Category:Sports venues in Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Oregon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1990]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Oregon]] {{coord|45|34|28|N|122|43|38|W|display=title}}

{{Infobox gymnast | name = Olivia Cîmpian | gender = w | country = {{ROU}} {{cite web|url=https://www.libertatea.ro/sport/gimnasta-olivia-cimpian-va-concura-iar-pentru-romania-2329540|title=Gimnasta Olivia Cîmpian va concura iar pentru România|date=15 July 2018|publisher=}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|2001|1|1|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Arad, Romania|Arad]] | discipline = WAG | level = Senior International Elite
([[Romania women's national gymnastics team|Romania national team]]) | show-medals = yes | medaltemplates = }} '''Olivia Cîmpian''' (born 1 January 2001) is a Romanian-born female [[artistic gymnast]]. At the 2016 Junior [[European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] she won the bronze medal with the Romanian team. She also competed at the 2017 [[European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] for Romania. However, as of July 2017, Cimpian has expressed her desire to compete for [[Hungary]] in future international meets.{{cite web |url=http://www.aradon.ro/bronz-european-pentru-olivia-cimpian/1650115 |title=Bronz european pentru Olivia Cîmpian |trans-title=|language= |author= |date= |website=Aradon.ro |access-date=7 July 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.aradon.ro/sol-de-aur-pentru-olivia-cimpian/1483928 |title=Sol de aur pentru Olivia Cimpian |trans-title=|language= |author= |date= |website=Aradon.ro |access-date=7 July 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ilfovsport.ro/dam-gimnaste-si-ungurilor-de-parca-noi-am-avea-destule-stoica-mai-vrei-un-mandat/ |title=Dăm gimnaste și ungurilor, de parcă noi am avea destule !! Stoica, mai vrei un mandat? |trans-title=|language= |author= |date=1 July 2017 |website=Ilfovsport.ro |access-date=7 July 2017}}[http://adevarul.ro/news/sport/a-lasat-romania-ungaria-cele-mai-promitatoare-gimnaste-ales-concureze-tara-vecina-initiativa-tatal-sau-e-fost-fotbalist-1_59f4ad4f5ab6550cb893005b/index.html A lăsat România pentru Ungaria. Una dintre cele mai promiţătoare gimnaste a ales să concureze pentru ţara vecină, la iniţiativa tatăl său, care e fost fotbalist], adevarul.ro, 29 October 2017 She eventually left for Hungary in July, and her nationality change became official in October.[http://www.fig-gymnastics.com/site/figNews/view?id=1924], FIG, 4 November 2017 Since athletes won’t be eligible to compete for a country for one year after they change nationality, Cimpian will barely be eligible for selection to Hungary’s team for the 2018 world championships. However that change was never official and Olivia decided she would compete again for Romania. ==Competitive history== {| border=1 cellpadding=1 cellspacing=2 style="border-collapse:collapse;
