revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name= Priestfield | image = [[File:Priestfield Stadium Medway Stand.jpg|200px]] | coordinates= {{coord|51|23|3.3|N|0|33|38.71|E|type:landmark_region:GB-KEN|display=inline,title}}| fullname = MEMS Priestfield Stadium | caption = External view of the Medway Stand | location = [[Gillingham, Medway|Gillingham]], Kent, England | nickname = | built = 1893 | opened = 1893 | seating_capacity = 11,582 | owner = [[Gillingham F.C.]] | operator = Gillingham F.C. | surface = Grass | tenants = [[Gillingham F.C.]] (1893–present)
[[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.]] (1997–99)
[[London Broncos]] (2012) | dimensions = {{convert|114|x|75|yd|m|1|lk=in}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oldhamathletic.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LeagueOneGrounds/0,,10337~1019469,00.html |publisher=Oldham Athletic F.C. |title=Priestfield |date=1 May 2007 |accessdate=7 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229062901/http://www.oldhamathletic.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LeagueOneGrounds/0%2C%2C10337~1019469%2C00.html |archivedate=29 December 2007 |df= }} }} '''Priestfield Stadium''' (popularly known simply as '''Priestfield''' and officially known from 2007 to 2010 as '''KRBS Priestfield Stadium''' and from 2011 as '''MEMS Priestfield Stadium''' for sponsorship purposes) is a [[Association football|football]] stadium in [[Gillingham, Medway|Gillingham]], Kent. It has been the home of [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham Football Club]] since the club's formation in 1893, and was also the temporary home of [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion Football Club]] for two seasons during the 1990s. The stadium has also hosted women's and youth international football matches and a [[London Broncos]] rugby league match. The stadium underwent extensive redevelopment during the late 1990s, which has brought its capacity down from nearly 20,000 to a current figure of 11,582. It has four [[all-seater]] stands, all constructed since 1997, although one is only of a temporary nature. There are also conference and banqueting facilities and a nightspot named The Factory. Despite having invested heavily in its current stadium, Gillingham F.C. has plans to relocate to a new stadium. == History == New Brompton Football Club, the forerunner of Gillingham Football Club, formed in June 1893. At the same time an area of land in Gillingham was acquired by the club's founders, the purchase being funded through an issue of 1,500 £1 shares.{{cite book | last = Triggs | first = Roger | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | publisher = Kent County Libraries | year = 1984 | isbn = | page = 7}} Sources differ on whether the stadium was named after the road on which the land stood, Priestfield Road,{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 8}} or whether the road was named after the stadium,{{cite web | url = http://www.medway.gov.uk/index/leisure/localhistory/timeline/17909/18624-2.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040903181001/http://www.medway.gov.uk/index/leisure/localhistory/timeline/17909/18624-2.htm | archivedate = 3 September 2004 | title = Local history: Gillingham Football Club |accessdate=11 April 2007 | publisher = Medway Council }} although until 1947 the stadium itself was officially named Priestfield Road.{{cite book | last = Bradley | first = Andy |author2=Roger Triggs | title = Home of the Shouting Men: Complete History of Gillingham Football Club 1893–1993 | publisher = Gillingham F.C. | year = 1994 | isbn = 0-9523361-0-3 | page =121}} A pitch was laid and a pavilion erected, and the first matches at Priestfield were staged on 2 September 1893. New Brompton's [[reserve team]] played [[Grays Athletic F.C.|Grays]], followed immediately by the first match for the club's [[first team]], against [[Arsenal F.C.|Woolwich Arsenal]]'s reserves. The admission charge for the two matches was 3d.{{cite book | last = Bradley | first = Andy |author2=Roger Triggs | title = Home of the Shouting Men: Complete History of Gillingham Football Club 1893–1993 | publisher = Gillingham F.C. | year = 1994 | isbn = 0-9523361-0-3 | page =16}} A newspaper report on the matches noted that the club had recently purchased an additional acre and three-quarters of ground and had accepted a contract for the construction of a stand containing 500 seats.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 4}} Most spectators stood on terracing, banked earth, or simply along the perimeter of the pitch, as was the case at most football grounds at the time.{{cite book | last=Davies | first=Hunter | title=Boots, Balls and Haircuts: An Illustrated History of Football from Then to Now |isbn=1-84403-261-2 |year=2003 |publisher=Cassell Illustrated |chapter=Chapter 5. Supporting Football: The History of Spectators | page=85}} In order to raise funds to assist with the running of the football club, New Brompton allowed the ground to be used for other events, such as smoking concerts, fêtes, athletics meetings and a ladies' football match. Sheep were allowed to graze on the pitch during the week, a common practice at many grounds at that time.{{cite book | last=Inglis | first=Simon | authorlink=Simon Inglis | title=The Football Grounds of England and Wales | year=1983 | publisher=Collins Willow | chapter=Chapter 18. South London and Kent |isbn=0-00-218024-3 | pages=243–245}} In 1899, a second stand was added along part of the Gordon Road side of the ground, reportedly built by off-duty dock workers in exchange for beer and cigarettes.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:IISC&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F8DA5B1B12EE7B7&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB57AB53DF815|title=Football: Chairmen take consolation from deadlock as Venables vows to battle on|author=Glenn Moore|work=The Independent |accessdate=5 November 2008|date=27 January 2003}} [[File:Priestfield1908.jpg|thumb|right|400px|A view of the ground in 1908, taken from the Rainham end of the ground]] By 1908, the total number of seats had been increased to 800 and terracing added at the [[Rainham, Kent|Rainham]] end of the ground. In 1912, the club's first Supporters' Association was formed, its initial project being to raise the necessary funds to construct terracing at the opposite end of the ground.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 6}} Two years later the club, which had changed its name to Gillingham F.C. in 1913, secured a bank loan of £1,570 which was used to build a new grandstand, but just a month after it was completed the stand was severely damaged by high winds, which ripped off the roof and twisted most of the ironwork. The club sued the contractors, but it took a further three months for the damage to be repaired.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 10}} A new attendance record was set in 1924 when an [[FA Cup]] match against [[Football League First Division|First Division]] leaders [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] drew a crowd of 19,472.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 12}} This record stood until 1948, when 23,002 fans watched Gillingham take on [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in the [[FA Cup]], with many more turned away. In the same year the club, which had lost its place in the [[Football League]] ten years earlier after failing to gain re-election, produced a glossy brochure as part of its bid to be elected back into the league. The facilities at Priestfield were highlighted as one of the club's strengths in the brochure, which listed the ground's capacity as "between 25,000 and 30,000" but stated that plans had been drawn up to increase the capacity to 50,000, with 5,000 seats.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | pages = 16–17}} [[File:Priestfield1.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The exterior of the Main Stand in the mid-1980s]] The ground underwent its most extensive redevelopment to date in 1955, at a total cost of £28,500. The previously sloping pitch was levelled, the terracing that occupied part of the Gordon Road side of the ground replaced, and new covered accommodation, known as the Stanley Stand, erected between the Rainham End and Gordon Road Stand.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 23}} The first floodlights were erected in 1963, at a cost of over £14,000, but this was to be the last significant development work at Priestfield for over thirty years.{{cite book | last = Triggs | title = Gillingham Football Club: A Chronology 1893–1984 | page = 25}} By the early 1980s the capacity of the ground was listed as 22,000,{{cite book | last = Soar | first = Phil |author2=Martin Tyler | title = Encyclopedia of British Football | publisher = Willow Books | year = 1983 | isbn = 0-00-218049-9 | page = 289}} although this was reduced to 19,000 when the Gordon Road Stand was closed for safety reasons.{{cite book | last = Bateson | first = Bill |author2=Albert Sewell | title = News of the World Football Annual 1989–90 | publisher = Invincible Press Ltd | year = 1989 | isbn = 0-85543-172-5 | page = 303}} In 1987, a clock was erected at the corner of the Rainham End and the Stanley Stand, dubbed the Lord Sondes Clock in honour of [[Henry Milles-Lade, 5th Earl Sondes]], a member of the club's board of directors. The clock was removed during later stadium redevelopment work.{{cite book | last = Elligate | first = David | title = Gillingham FC On This Day | publisher = Pitch Publishing | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-1-905411-45-0 | page =52}} New owner [[Paul Scally]] took over at the club in 1995 and soon instigated a programme of redevelopment which completely transformed the formerly run-down ground. The closed stand was replaced with a new Gordon Road Stand in 1997 at a cost of more than £2 million. Two years later the Rainham End terracing was replaced with a new all-seater stand, with the sports centre behind it demolished and replaced with a car park.{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/PriestfieldStadium/0,,10416,00.html |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |title=The Changing Face of KRBS Priestfield |date=7 September 2007 |accessdate=6 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115155957/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/PriestfieldStadium/0%2C%2C10416%2C00.html |archivedate=15 November 2007 |df= }} [[File:RainhamEndGordonRoadStand.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Rainham End and Gordon Road Stand during a match in 2007]] The main stand on the northern side of the pitch was demolished in 1999, along with a section of away terracing, to be replaced with a new state-of-the-art facility dubbed the Medway Stand, but the work was beset by problems. Due to serious delays with the building of the new stand, the club was forced to spend most of the subsequent season first with that side of the ground completely empty, then later with building work ongoing. Supporters were not able to sit in the new stand until the latter stages of the [[1999–2000 in English football|1999–2000 season]], and even then many of the facilities had not been finished. The stand also caused severe financial problems for the club, as its facilities eventually cost significantly more than the original estimate.{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11737_2224411,00.html|title=Gills May Be Forced to Sell|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=2 October 2008|author=Stephen Bateman}} The fourth side of the ground was redeveloped in 2003 when the Town End terracing was removed and a temporary stand put in its place, named after the late football commentator and Gillingham supporter [[Brian Moore (commentator)|Brian Moore]]. It was hoped that work would begin on a permanent Brian Moore Stand in 2004, but due to talk of relocating the club to a new ground and the club's current financial problems, this has been put on hold.{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/aroundthegrounds/Gillingham---Priestfield-Stadium.2984470.jp|title=Gillingham – Priestfield Stadium|work=Yorkshire Evening Post|accessdate=7 November 2007|date=27 June 2007}} On 1 June 2007, the stadium was officially renamed '''KRBS Priestfield Stadium''' as part of a sponsorship deal that lasted three years with the [[Kent Reliance Building Society]].{{Cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/g/gillingham/6465713.stm | title = Gillingham to change stadium name |accessdate=8 January 2008 |date=19 March 2007 |publisher=BBC }} In 2011 another such deal led to the rebranding of the stadium as '''MEMS Priestfield Stadium'''.{{cite web|date=23 May 2011 |url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/page/PressReleases/0,,10416~2355939,00.html |title=New sponsor named..... |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |accessdate=7 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512145850/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/page/PressReleases/0%2C%2C10416~2355939%2C00.html |archivedate=12 May 2011 |df= }} == Structure and facilities == [[File:PlanOfPriestfield.png|thumb|right|300px|A plan of the stadium's layout]] The pitch is surrounded by four [[All-seater stadium|all-seater stands]] – the Medway Stand, the Rainham End, the Gordon Road Stand and the Brian Moore Stand. All are covered with the exception of the Brian Moore Stand. The Medway Stand, which replaced the old Main Stand and part of the terracing at each end, is the largest and northernmost of the four. It has two tiers with a row of twenty executive boxes between the top and bottom tier. The stand also contains the changing rooms, physiotherapy facilities, club offices and club shop. The Rainham End, located behind the goal at the eastern end of the pitch, opened in 1999 and houses 2,400 fans. This stand, like the terrace it replaced, is known for housing the club's most vocal supporters.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsf.org.uk/ground-guide/stadiums/gillingham/priestfield-stadium/ |title=Gillingham |publisher=Football Supporters' Federation |accessdate=8 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014213458/http://fsf.org.uk/ground-guide/stadiums/gillingham/priestfield-stadium/ |archivedate=14 October 2007 }} The Gordon Road Stand, which seats 2,600, was opened in 1997 and is opposite the Medway Stand. Due to planning requirements, the stand had a height restriction placed upon it, making it significantly lower than the other three sides of the ground, and due to the road layout behind it is narrower at one end than the other. A gantry for television cameras is located on the roof of this stand.{{cite web|url=http://www.lutontown.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10372~1130322,00.html |title=Gillingham Travel Details |publisher=Luton Town F.C. |accessdate=5 November 2008 |date=9 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003075224/http://www.lutontown.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10372~1130322%2C00.html |archivedate=3 October 2011 |df= }} [[File:Priestfield2.jpg|400px|thumb|left|The slope of the old Gillingham End is apparent in this photo from the mid-1980s.]] Opposite the Rainham End is the Brian Moore Stand. This stand is a temporary one, and accommodates visiting supporters.{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/TravelMatchPack/0,,10416~405497,00.html |title=Travel match pack |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |accessdate=8 November 2007 |date=20 April 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040624104139/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/TravelMatchPack/0%2C%2C10416~405497%2C00.html |archivedate=24 June 2004 |df= }} It occupies the site of the former Town End terracing, which was unusual in that it had a pronounced slope, with one end of the terracing being higher up than the other. In 1955 the pitch, which previously sloped at that end of the stadium, was levelled out but the gradient of the Town End was left unchanged. The state of the stadium's pitch caused the club severe problems in 2003. A number of fixtures had to be postponed due to the state of the pitch,{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/TheFACup/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2003/01/36341.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20050413044006/http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/TheFACup/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2003/01/36341.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 April 2005 |title=Gills topple Wednesday|publisher=The Football Association|accessdate=22 November 2007|date=8 January 2003}} which was described as resembling a ploughed field,{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2003/03/05/sfggil05.xml |title=Huckerby class tells|work=The Daily Telegraph|author=Steve Thomson|accessdate=22 November 2007|date=4 March 2003}} and the surface had to be heavily sanded before an [[FA Cup]] match against [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/2671827.stm|title=Leeds held at Gillingham|publisher=BBC|accessdate=22 November 2007|date=13 February 2003}} At the end of the season, taking advantage of the demolition of the old Town End, which allowed better access to the pitch, the club had the drainage system replaced and a completely new pitch laid. [[File:BrianMooreStand2012.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The current Brian Moore Stand, at the Gillingham end of the stadium, has been constructed on a temporary basis only.]] Added to the new stands were several new developments. The Conference and Banqueting Centre, which is located behind the Rainham End, comprises the Great Hall, which can accommodate up to 600 delegates for events, and twenty smaller delegate rooms.{{cite web|url=http://www.priestfield.com/|title=Priestfield Conference & Banqueting|accessdate=5 November 2008|publisher=Gillingham F.C}} The Centre is connected to the Medway Stand, thus allowing views from the banqueting suite onto the pitch, and is also licensed for wedding ceremonies.{{cite web|url=http://www.medway.gov.uk/index/community/registeroffice/ceremonyvenues/27958.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070907171719/http://www.medway.gov.uk/index/community/registeroffice/ceremonyvenues/27958.htm|archivedate=7 September 2007|title=Birth, death and marriage registration|publisher=Medway Council|accessdate=8 November 2007}} The Blues Rock Café nightspot, located within the Medway Stand, is open between four and five nights a week and stages live music and screenings of major sporting events.{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/BluesCafe/0,,10416,00.html |title=Details of the club's premier nightspot |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |accessdate=8 November 2007 |date=7 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115155753/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/BluesCafe/0%2C%2C10416%2C00.html |archivedate=15 November 2007 |df= }} The club purchased many of the fixtures and fittings for these new developments at discounted prices when the furnishings of the [[Millennium Dome]] were sold off upon its closure.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20030119/ai_n9682090|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611184146/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20030119/ai_n9682090|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 June 2008|title=Football: He paid £1 for the club. Now the Gills are quids in|work=The Independent on Sunday|author=Steve Tongue|accessdate=8 November 2007|date=19 January 2003}} Despite the stadium's new facilities, Priestfield is still viewed in a negative light in some circles. In 2004, it was voted the worst football ground in England by a poll in the [[The Observer|Observer]] newspaper, although most of the comments made in the poll concerned the town of Gillingham itself, rather than the actual stadium as a building.{{cite news|url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,1563,1324085,00.html|title=Simply the worst|work=The Observer |author=Gemma Clarke|accessdate=5 November 2007|date=10 October 2004}} == Future == Gillingham chairman [[Paul Scally]] has made it clear that he intends to relocate the club away from its current stadium, announcing in September 2003 that "there is no future for the club at the Priestfield".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/g/gillingham/3130036.stm|title=Scally considers Gills future|publisher=BBC|accessdate=5 November 2007|date=22 September 2003}} In 2004, the club outlined plans for a new stadium at [[Cuxton]] but abandoned them soon afterwards due to the cost of improving transport links to the site. At the time Scally stated that he anticipated the club moving within four years,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/3857867.stm|title=Gillingham vow to remain in Kent|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 November 2007|date=1 July 2004}} but by 2007 the proposed date had been pushed back to 2010.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/g/gillingham/6286217.stm|title=Gills targeting 2010 stadium move|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 November 2007|date=22 January 2007}} In March 2017, he again identified Mill Hill, on the east of the A289 Yokosuka Way, as his preferred site for a new stadium, re-iterated that this was necessary for the club to have ambitions of future [[Premier League]] football, and that he would be launching a bond scheme to fund the early stages of the development.{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/documents/gfc-supporters-letter-rev166-3639162.pdf|title=A letter to all supporters from the chairman|publisher=Gillingham F.C.|accessdate=23 March 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170324085317/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/documents/gfc-supporters-letter-rev166-3639162.pdf|archivedate=24 March 2017|df=dmy-all}} Despite the proposed move, the club promoted its facilities, in conjunction with [[Medway]] Council, as a possible training base for athletes competing in the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], saying:{{cite web|url=http://www.medway.gov.uk/london2012/55326/56285.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630233023/http://www.medway.gov.uk/london2012/55326/56285.htm|archivedate=30 June 2007|title=Gillingham Football Club|publisher=Medway Council|accessdate=6 November 2007}}{{cquote|The Medway Stand is fully equipped with physio rooms, a hydrotherapy pool, a sauna and steam rooms to assist with the athletes' training, and a lounge bar, a cinema and a snooker room for them to enjoy during their free time. The club's offices, media centre and press room could also provide the coaches with a good administrative base. We are excited about the prospect of international athletes benefiting from our excellent facilities in preparation for London 2012.}} In December 2007, Gillingham shareholders passed a resolution to sell the ground to Priestfield Developments Ltd, a company wholly owned by Paul Scally, for £9.8m as part of a restructuring of the club's debts. The deal was to allow three years use of the stadium at £1 p.a., with the club meeting running costs, with tenure secured for a further seven years at a rent as yet unspecified.{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10416~1196619,00.html |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |title=Results from the EGM |accessdate=22 December 2007 |date=21 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105063132/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10416~1196619%2C00.html |archivedate=5 January 2008 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10416~1184435,00.html |title=A Note from the Chairman |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |accessdate=22 December 2007 |date=22 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213191017/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10416~1184435%2C00.html |archivedate=13 December 2007 |df= }} In 2011, however, the club purchased the stadium back for around 10% of the fee paid by Priestfield Developments.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jul/21/gillingham-buy-back-priestfield-stadium|title=Mystery of £1m deal for Gillingham to buy back Priestfield Stadium|work=The Guardian|date=21 July 2011|accessdate=30 August 2012|first=Matt|last=Scott}} == Other uses == In April 2006, the ground hosted the [[England women's national football team|England women's team]]'s [[FIFA Women's World Cup|World Cup Qualifier]] against [[Austria women's national football team|Austria]], achieving a gate of 8,068 (a higher attendance than Gillingham's average home gate for the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season).{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/women/4931222.stm | title = Powell impressed with Kent crowd |accessdate=7 November 2007 |date=21 April 2006 |publisher=BBC }}{{cite web | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/stats/attendance?league=eng.3&year=2005&cc=3888 | title = English League One – Attendance – Final |accessdate=5 November 2008 | publisher = ESPN }} Priestfield has also been the venue for home matches for the [[England national under-18 football team|England youth team]], including a November 2007 match against their counterparts from [[Ghana]].{{cite web |url=http://www.htafc.com/page/AcademyNewsDetail/0%2C%2C10312~1172503%2C00.html |title=Smithies plays for England again |accessdate=16 September 2010 |publisher=Huddersfield Town F.C. |date=21 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308034914/http://www.htafc.com/page/AcademyNewsDetail/0%2C%2C10312~1172503%2C00.html |archivedate=8 March 2009 |df= }} The stadium has also occasionally been the "home" of clubs other than Gillingham. In 1895, [[Arsenal F.C.|Woolwich Arsenal]] played a [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] home game against [[Burton Swifts F.C.|Burton Swifts]] at Priestfield after their own [[Manor Ground, Plumstead|Manor Ground]] had been closed by the Football League for five weeks after [[football hooliganism|crowd trouble]] at a match there earlier that year.{{cite book | author=Hayes, Dean | title=Arsenal: The Football Facts | publisher=John Blake | year=2007 | isbn=1-84454-433-8 | page= 268 }} Over a century later, during the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98]] and [[1998–99 in English football|1998–99]] seasons [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] played their home matches at Priestfield, as they had entered a ground-share agreement with [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] as a result of the sale of their [[Goldstone Ground]] to property developers.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brighton/1114445.stm|title=Gulls reach Gills settlement|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 November 2007|date=12 January 2001}} The move, undertaken by the club after a plan to groundshare with [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] fell through,{{Cite news | url = http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/indepth/falmerstadium/decadeofheadlines/ | title = Sad tale has a happy ending | accessdate=15 November 2007 |author=Simon Barrett |work = The Argus }} was a controversial one for Brighton's fans, who faced a {{convert|150|mi|km|sing=on}} round trip to each home game.{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/1999/05/04/sfnhay04.html |title=Talking Football: No fond farewell from the club that would not die |accessdate=15 November 2007 |author=Paul Hayward |date=4 May 1999 |work=The Daily Telegraph |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612045646/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F1999%2F05%2F04%2Fsfnhay04.html |archivedate=12 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/commentary-brightons-home-day-blues-1246014.html | title=Commentary: Brighton's home day blues | accessdate=15 November 2007 | author=Glenn Moore | date=18 August 1997 | work=The Independent }} The two clubs subsequently became embroiled in a dispute over the charges levied by Gillingham for the hire of the ground, which was eventually settled out of court in 2001. In May 2012 the [[London Broncos]] hosted a [[rugby league]] match at the stadium, the first [[Super League]] match to be staged in Kent,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_league/16759266.stm|title=London Broncos to play Super League match at Gillingham|date=27 January 2012|accessdate=27 January 2012|publisher=BBC}} and the club later announced the possibility of making Priestfield their permanent home venue with effect from 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/rugby-league/news/12212/8005428?|title=Broncos poised for switch|publisher=Sky Sports, Inc|accessdate=20 August 2012}} although this did not occur. The social and catering facilities are used for a range of business and entertainment events, and the premises is licensed for marriages. The pitch area and the Gordon Road Stand were used for a Christian outreach festival in May 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.inn.org.uk/inntro/history.html |title=Inn-troduction |publisher=Inn Christian Ministries, Inc |accessdate=22 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031219000539/http://www.inn.org.uk/inntro/history.html |archivedate=19 December 2003 }} == Records == [[File:GillsGates.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Average home league attendances since Gillingham returned to the Football League in 1950]] The highest attendance recorded at Priestfield was 23,002 for a match against [[Queens Park Rangers]] in the [[FA Cup]] 3rd round on 10 January 1948.{{cite book | last = Brown | first = Tony | title = The Definitive Gillingham F.C.: A Complete Record | publisher = Soccerdata | year = 2003 | isbn = 1-899468-20-X | page =3}} The highest [[Football League]] attendance was 20,128 against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in the [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] on 2 September 1950.{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/ClubHistory/0,,10416,00.html |title=Gillingham F.C. History (1893– ) |publisher=Gillingham F.C. |accessdate=8 November 2007 |date=9 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115155803/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/ClubHistory/0%2C%2C10416%2C00.html |archivedate=15 November 2007 |df= }} The record modern (all-seated) attendance is 11,418, set on 20 September 2003 against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fsf.org.uk/ground-guide/clubs/gillingham/ |title=Gillingham |publisher=Football Supporters' Federation |accessdate=5 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014213009/http://fsf.org.uk/ground-guide/clubs/gillingham/ |archivedate=14 October 2007 }} The highest seasonal average attendance for league matches at Priestfield since Gillingham returned to the [[Football League]] in 1950 was 12,576 in the [[1951–52 in English football|1951–52]] season.{{cite book | last = Brown | first = Tony | title = The Definitive Gillingham F.C.: A Complete Record | page =61}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/page/Attendance/0,,10416~200210416,00.html |title=Attendance |publisher=Gillingham F.C |accessdate=5 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724173138/http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/page/Attendance/0%2C%2C10416~200210416%2C00.html |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }} Gillingham's lowest seasonal average was 2,979 in the [[1994–95 in English football|1994–95]] season,{{cite book | last = Brown | first = Tony | title = The Definitive Gillingham F.C.: A Complete Record | page =104}} although Brighton recorded a lower figure of 2,328 in the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98]] season.{{cite web |url = http://stats.football365.com/1998/ENG/LGE/attend.html |title = English Leagues – 1997–1998 Season Domestic Stats – Attendance Table |accessdate = 5 November 2008 |publisher = Football365 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080514054933/http://stats.football365.com/1998/ENG/LGE/attend.html |archivedate = 14 May 2008 |df = dmy-all }} == Transport == {{main article|Gillingham (Kent) railway station}} The stadium is approximately {{convert|0.5|mi|km|0}} from [[Gillingham (Kent) railway station|Gillingham railway station]], which lies on [[Southeastern (train operating company)|Southeastern]]'s [[Chatham Main Line]] from [[Victoria Station (London)|London Victoria]] to [[Dover Priory railway station|Dover Priory]] and [[Ramsgate railway station|Ramsgate]]. The station is also the southern terminus of the [[North Kent Line]], which connects to [[Charing Cross railway station|London Charing Cross]].{{cite web|url=http://www.livedepartureboards.co.uk/ldb/summary.aspx?T=GLM|title=Live Departures: Gillingham (Kent) (GLM)|accessdate=8 November 2007|publisher=National Rail Enquiries}} The stadium has no parking facilities for supporters, and the streets around the ground are subject to a residents-only permit parking scheme on match days, which means that supporters have to park a considerable distance away from the ground. For the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08]] season the club introduced a park and ride scheme whereby supporters leave their cars in a car park approximately one mile from the ground and are transported to the stadium by taxi.{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterroversfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/0,,10329~1156155,00.html |title=Park and Ride Available at Gillingham |accessdate=8 November 2007 |publisher=Doncaster Rovers F.C. |date=5 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217155152/http://www.doncasterroversfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/0%2C%2C10329~1156155%2C00.html |archivedate=17 December 2007 |df= }} Chairman [[Paul Scally]] has cited the lack of parking as one of the main reasons why a new stadium is essential.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/3633315.stm|title= Gillingham unveil new ground plan |accessdate=8 November 2007|publisher=BBC|date=16 April 2004}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081207022013/http://www.bbc.co.uk/kent/places/pans/gillingham/gillingham_01.shtml Panorama of the ground from BBC Kent] * [http://www.priestfield.com/ Priestfield Conference & Banqueting] {{Featured article}} {{Gillingham F.C.}} {{Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.}} {{Football League One Venues}} {{commons category|Priestfield Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues in Kent]] [[Category:Gillingham F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1893]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.]]

revision.comment: /* References */ not used in austrlaian football
revision.text:
{{About|the sports term|survey roads|concession road|other uses|Sideline (disambiguation){{!}}Sideline}} [[File:Walter & Russell at Falcons at Raiders 11-2-08.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Players not actively participating in a game and coaches remain on the sidelines during play]]
The '''"sidelines"''' are the white or colored lines which mark the outer boundaries of a sports field, running parallel to each other and perpendicular to the [[Goal line (American football)|goal line]]s.<ref>http://www.sportingcharts.com/dictionary/nfl/sidelines.aspx</ref> The sidelines are also where the coaching staff and players out of play operate during a game. The area outside the sidelines is said to be [[out of bounds]]. The term is predominantly in use in [[American football]], [[Canadian football]], [[field lacrosse]] and [[basketball]]. [[File:TO EaglesCowboys Sideline.jpg|left|thumb|250px|In gridiron football, a player who steps onto the sidelines during play is considered to be [[out of bounds]]]] In [[rugby union]], [[rugby league]] and [[association football]], they are known as [[touch-line]]s. The foul line is a similar concept in [[baseball]]. Sports in which the playing surface is bounded by walls, such as [[ice hockey]], [[box lacrosse]], and [[indoor American football|indoor football]], do not use sidelines; in these sports, coaches and reserve players are positioned in recessed benches behind the walls.
The sideline can be used metaphorically to refer to players who have been "benched", meaning that they have been taken out of the game purposefully by the coaching staff due to poor performance in the game or previous play. Establishing shots of these players may be used by televised sports programs to indicate potential roster switches, or to build a narrative of the failure or success of the coaching staff's decision. Likewise, images of the sideline may suggest that the highlighted player had done something of interest outside the confines of play. For example, in American football, [[Gatorade shower|dousing the head coach with water or sports drink]] is a popular way of celebrating crucial victories, established as a tradition by the [[New York Giants]] of the [[National Football League]] in the mid-1980s.
The term "to be sidelined" refers to a player in a sports event who is unable to play (e.g. confined to the sideline) for injury, suspension, or other similar reasons. This term has spread into a business context; a project that has been "sidelined" is no longer a major concern or objective of the proponent company.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{American football concepts}}

revision.text:
'''Snow snake''' is a Native American [[winter sport]] traditionally played by many tribes in the northern Midwest, including the [[Ojibwe]], [[Sioux]], [[Wyandotte people|Wyandotte]], [[Oneida people|Oneida]] and other [[Iroquois people]].<ref name=minn>{{cite news |title=Snow snakes: Native game lives on in Minnesota's frozen winter |author=Jeff Horwich |url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2003/01/27_horwichj_snowsnake/ |newspaper=Minnesota Public Radio |date=28 January 2003 |accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref><ref name=rite>{{cite news |title=Learning to Play Snow Snake Is a 'Sacred Rite of Passage' |author=ICTMN Staff |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/article/learning-to-play-snow-snake-is-a-sacred-rite-of-passage-70378 |newspaper=Indian Country Today Media Network |date=3 January 2012 |accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref>
==Play== A game of snow snake is played by four teams, called "corners", who compete in trying to throw their wooden "snow snakes" the farthest along a long trough, or track, of snow. The game is divided into rounds, and in a round each team gets four throws. At the end of each round, two points are awarded to the team of the person who made the farthest throw in the round, and one point is awarded for the second farthest throw. Play continues until one of the teams wins, by achieving a certain predetermined number of points (usually 7 or 11).<ref name=gan>{{cite web |url=http://www.ganondagan.org/articles/SnowSnake.html |title=Snow Snake, a Sport Steeped in Tradition |last1=Llewellyn |first1=Carol White |year=2009 |work=Ganondagan |publisher=Friends of Ganondagan |accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref>
There are two roles on a snow snake team: the Player, and the Goaler. The main role of a Goaler is to craft and maintain a team's wooden "snow snakes" in between games. The Goaler is also tasked with selecting which will be used for each throw during the game. A Player, meanwhile, is a player who actually throws the snow snakes during a game.<ref name=gan />
==Equipment== The poles used in the game, collectively known as "snow snakes", have different names depending on their length. The smallest poles used are the six-inch-long "snow darts".<ref name=minn /> The next size up is the three-foot-long "short snake",<ref name=onon>{{cite web |url=http://www.onondaganation.org/culture/sports_snowsnake.html |title=SPORTS - Snowsnake |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2007 |work=Onondanga Nation: People of the Hills |publisher=Onondanga Nation |accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref> also known as a "mud cat".<ref name=gan /> Longer poles are known only as "snow snakes", and can be anywhere from six to ten feet in length.<ref name=minn /> Snow snakes can be made from a variety of materials. In the Sioux tribe, they were traditionally made of bone, with feathers trailing behind for symbolic decoration,<ref name=minn /> while other tribes traditionally used native North American hardwoods, such as [[maple]], [[oak]], [[malus|apple]], [[hickory]], and [[juneberry]].<ref name=gan /> In modern times, other hardwoods not traditionally available, such as [[ebony]], have become popular materials for snow snakes.<ref name=gan /> Many players customize their snow snakes, by decorating them with colorful designs, or adding minor modifications, such as waxing the wooden surface.<ref name=minn />
The trough, or track, that snow snakes are thrown down is typically five inches deep, rising up in a slope at the end where the players stand.<ref name=gan /> In modern times, some groups will add obstacles like jumps or snow barriers to their tracks, for added interest.<ref name=minn />
==History== According to the Iroquois oral tradition, the game of snow snake dates back more than 500 years, to before the arrival of Europeans in North America. Originally a form of communication between villages, the throwing of "snow snakes" in a trough of snow developed into a competitive sport during long winters when the long track was not used for communication.<ref name=gan /> The name "snow snake" is said to have come from the serpentine wiggling motion of the poles as they slide down the icy track.<ref name=rite />
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Native American sports and games]] [[Category:Winter sports]] [[Category:Great Lakes tribal culture]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Stadio Angelo Massimino | nickname = Cibali| image = [[File:Cibalisettoreospiti.jpg|250px]]| location = [[Catania]], Italy| broke_ground = 1937 | opened = 1937 | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of [[Catania]]| operator = | surface = Grass| construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Stadio Cibali | tenants = [[Calcio Catania]] (1937–43, 1946–present)
[[Italy national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity =
23,266{{cite web |url=http://www.osservatoriosport.interno.it/allegati/impianti/impianti_superiori_7500.pdf |title=Impianti superiori a 7500 posti, dati del Comitato Nazionale di Informazione sulle Manifestazioni Sportive |access-date=7 September 2009 |publisher=osservatoriosport.interno.it |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721225554/http://www.osservatoriosport.interno.it/allegati/impianti/impianti_superiori_7500.pdf |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} | }} '''Stadio Angelo Massimino''' (previously known as '''Stadio Cibali''') is a multi-use stadium in [[Catania]], Italy. It is used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches and the home of [[Calcio Catania]]. The stadium was built in 1935 by architect Raffaele Leone on behalf of the company owned by the engineer Antonio Ferro and holds 20,266. It was renamed in 2002 after former Catania chairman [[Angelo Massimino]]. [[Calcio Catania|Catania]] was banned from playing any [[Serie A]] matches inside the stadium from 14 February 2007 until 30 June 2007.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/6361463.stm|title=Catania lose stadium ban appeal|date=22 February 2007|accessdate=1 November 2010|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}} This was due to the violence that occurred on 2 February 2007 outside the stadium in the [[2007 Catania football violence|clash]] against [[U.S._Citt%C3%A0_di_Palermo|Palermo]] which resulted in the death of a Police Officer. ==External links== *[http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3195/2761488498_096f7fae32.jpg Stadium picture] *[http://www.kopane.de/stadio-angelo-massimino-catania/ images from the stadium, data and match visits at Kopane.de] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Calcio Catania}} {{Serie A venues}} {{Serie C stadiums}} {{coord|37|30|57|N|15|4|17|E|type:landmark_region:IT|display=title}} [[Category:Calcio Catania|Venue]] [[Category:Football venues in Italy|Angelo Massimino]] [[Category:Sports venues in Catania]] [[Category:1937 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1937]] [[Category:Serie A venues|Angelo]] {{Italy-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox horseraces | class = Discontinued stakes | horse race = Twin City Handicap | website = | image = | caption = | location = [[Belmont Park]]
[[Elmont, New York]], [[United States]] | inaugurated = 1884 - 1930 | race type = [[Thoroughbred]] - [[Flat racing]] | distance = {{frac|1|1|4}} miles (10 furlongs) | surface = Dirt | track = left-handed | qualification = Three-years-old and up | weight = | purse = }} The '''Twin City Handicap''' was an American [[Thoroughbred racing|Thoroughbred horse race]] first run in 1884 at [[Sheepshead Bay Race Track]] in [[Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn|Sheepshead Bay]], [[New York (state)|New York]] where it continued annually through 1909.{{cite web|url=https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1900s/drf1909090201/drf1909090201_1_8 |title=The Twin City Handicap |publisher=Daily Racing Form at University of Kentucky Archives |date=1909-09-02 |accessdate=2018-10-11}} Following passage by the [[New York State Legislature]] of the [[Hart–Agnew Law]] anti-wagering [[Bill (law)|bill]] that resulted in the closure of all racetracks in the state of New York.{{cite web|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/12/08/118496663.pdf|title=RACING FUNDS FOR THE CLERGY; Amasa Thernton Got $250 on Account to interest Friendly Ministers. MUTUAL BANK LEDGER LOST In It Was the Expense Account of the Bookmakers for the Year of the Bribery Scandal. BELMONT STIRRED TO WRATH Insists That Linn Bruce of Committee's Counsel Is Trying to Trip Him and Declines to Answer Questions. RACING FUNDS FOR THE CLERGY|author=|date=|website=NYTimes.com|access-date=September 2, 2017}} The devastation to the horse racing industry was such that the Sheepshead Bay Race Track never reopened.{{cite web|url=https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1900s/drf1908071701/drf1908071701_1_8 |title=Twin City Handicap Cut To $3,000|publisher=Daily Racing Form at University of Kentucky Archives |date=1908-07-17 |accessdate=2018-10-11}} On September 2, 1909 [[Olambala]] won what would prove to be the final running of the Twin City Handicap at the Sheepshead Bay track. {{cite web|url=https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1900s/drf1909090301/drf1909090301_1_2 |title=Olambala Triumphs over Hildreth Crack in Twin City Handicap |publisher=Daily Racing Form at University of Kentucky Archives |date= 1909-09-03 |accessdate=2017-10-12}} In 1917 the Coney Island Jockey Club, operators of the Sheepshead Bay Race Track, transferred their race titles to [[The Jockey Club]].{{cite web|url=https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1910s/drf1917082201/drf1917082201_2_9 |title=Donate Title to Old Stakes |publisher=Daily Racing Form at University of Kentucky Archives |date= 1917-08-17 |accessdate=2018-10-16}} As a result, in 1924 [[Belmont Park]] revived the Twin City Handicap. Won by Spot Cash, the first event at Belmont Park was run on a track made sloppy by a heavy rainstorm that the jockeys and their horses had to endure.{{cite web|url=https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1920s/drf1924091001/drf1924091001_1_8 |title=Spot Cash In Front: Races through Heavy Rainstorm |publisher=Daily Racing Form at University of Kentucky Archives |date= 1924-09-10 |accessdate=2017-10-12}} Although the next few years saw the race continue to attract top level runners, the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929|Wall Street Crash of October 29, 1929]] and ensuing [[Great Depression]] brought further setbacks to horse racing and the race would be canceled. The final running of the Twin City Handicap took place on September 11, 1930 when future [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|U.S. Racing Hall of Fame]] inductee [[Raymond Workman]] guided [[James Butler (grocer)|James Butler]]'s three-year-old colt [[Questionnaire (horse)|Questionnaire]] to a two-length victory while being eased up.{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/59866953/ |title=Questionnaire Rounds Out Ninth Victory by Winning Twin City 'Cap |publisher=Brooklyn Daily Eagle (Brooklyn, New York) Page 26|date= 1930-09-12|accessdate=2017-06-05}} ==Records== '''Speed record:''' * 2:02 4/5 - 1 1/4 miles on dirt: [[Questionnaire (horse)|Questionnaire]] (1930) '''Most wins:''' * 3 - Exile (1888, 1889) '''Most wins by a [[jockey]]:''' * 5 - [[Anthony Hamilton (jockey)|Anthony Hamilton]] (1886, 1888, 1889, 1892, 1894) '''Most wins by a [[Horse trainer|trainer]]:''' * 2 - [[Green B. {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Wings Event Center | former_names = Wings Stadium (1974–2015) | nickname = | image = Toledo Walleye vs. Kalamazoo Wings January 2014 23.jpg | location = 3600 Vanrick Drive
[[Kalamazoo, Michigan]] 49001 | broke_ground = February 1974 | built = | opened = October 30, 1974{{cite web|url=http://www.kwings.com/history.php |title=Kalamazoo Wings official website |accessdate=September 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013074001/http://www.kwings.com/history.php |archivedate=October 13, 2011 }} | closed = | demolished = | owner = Stadium Management Company | operator = Stadium Management Company | surface = [[Ice_hockey#Game|Ice]] | construction_cost = | architect = Richard A. Schramm | tenants = [[Kalamazoo Wings (1974–2000)|Kalamazoo Wings]] ([[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|IHL]]) (1974–2000)
[[Kalamazoo Kangaroos]] ([[National Professional Soccer League (1984–2001)|AISA]]) (1984–1986)
[[Kalamazoo Wings]] ([[ECHL]]) (2000–present)
[[Kalamazoo Xplosion]] ([[Continental Indoor Football League|CIFL]]) (2007–2008) | seating_capacity = 5,113 (Ice Hockey, Indoor Football, Basketball)
8,023 (Other) }} '''Wings Event Center''' (formerly '''Wings Stadium''') is a 5,113-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] located in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]]. The arena opened in 1974 and is home to the [[Kalamazoo Wings]], an [[ice hockey]] team in the [[ECHL]]. The stadium changed the name to the Wings Event Center on March 25, 2015 to market the arenas other hosting capabilities to companies and promoters.{{cite web |url=http://www.wingseventcenter.com/press_release.aspx?p=23 |title=WINGS STADIUM IS NOW THE WINGS EVENT CENTER |publisher=Wings Event Center |date=March 25, 2015}} The complex features four concession stands and two bars along the concourse, as well as the Underground Sports Bar. The main arena is a part of a sports and convention complex serving southwest [[Michigan]]. As a [[concert]] venue, the stadium can seat up to 8,023; as a convention center it can accommodate {{convert|17000|sqft|m2|-2}} of trade show and exhibit space. Along with numerous concerts, the stadium has also hosted a number of [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE) events. In 1989, the Annex, seating 1,367 for hockey and up to 2,850 for other events, was added; it also has {{convert|17000|sqft|m2|-2}} of arena floor space and can be used for hockey, curling, trade shows, conventions and other events. It also has a {{convert|3166|sqft|m2|0|sing=on}} viewing area. The Cube, the third arena in the complex, was added in 1997, and is used for hockey and trade shows; its arena floor also measures {{convert|17000|sqft|m2|-2}}, bringing the total exhibit space to {{convert|51000|sqft|m2|-2}}. There is also a {{convert|5800|sqft|m2|-1|sing=on}} viewing area at the arena. The complex has a {{convert|2500|sqft|m2|-1|sing=on}} lobby and a {{convert|500|sqft|m2|0|sing=on}} hospitality room, a separate concession stand and a bar called the Icehouse by Old Burdick's, which overlooks the Annex. ==Gallery== File:Toledo Walleye vs. Kalamazoo Wings January 2014 01.jpg|Wings Stadium exterior File:Toledo Walleye vs. Kalamazoo Wings January 2014 03.jpg|Wings Stadium interior File:Toledo Walleye vs. Kalamazoo Wings January 2014 22.jpg|Wings Stadium interior ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline|Wings Stadium}} *[http://www.wingseventcenter.com/default.aspx Wings Event Center Homepage] {{coord|42|15|13|N|85|32|7|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{ECHL Arenas}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Michigan]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Convention centers in Michigan]] [[Category:Sports venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kalamazoo, Michigan]] [[Category:Sports in Kalamazoo, Michigan]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Kalamazoo, Michigan]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Michigan]]
